text:
Broadway, east side, north from East 9th Street (right), showing prominently the A. T. Stewart store and Grace Church. These are to the south and north of 10th Street respectively. The department store occupies the north half of the block at this date. In 1868 this will be enlarged from plans by George Kellum and become Hilton, Hughes & Co. The site of Grace Church was purchased in 1843 and the cornerstone laid on October 30, 1843. The church was consecrated on March 7, 1846.

About 1860.

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Neg. # 809

The same, at an earlier date.  Note the 3-story buildings on the right (S.E. corner of East 9th Street) that today (1937) have been replaced by the south building of Wanamakers.  In the center of the view, between Grace Church and the north building of A.T. Stewarts (now Wanamakers) is barely discernible Fleishmann's Vienna Model Bakery; a structure that stood on the N.E. corner of East 10th Street until 1908.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

The same, at an earlier date.  Note the 3-story buildings on the right (S.E. corner of East 9th Street) that today (1937) have been replaced by the south building of Wanamakers.  In the center of the view, between Grace Church and the north building of A.T. Stewarts (now Wanamakers) is barely discernible Fleishmann's Vienna Model Bakery; a structure that stood on the N.E. corner of East 10th Street until 1908.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

Broadway, east side, north from East 9th Street (right), showing the old Stewart store and Grace Church. Separating these is Fleishmann's Vienna Model Bakery on the north side of 10th Street. The sign on the Stewart
building reads Sylvester ------- and Co.
About 1880
Thru New York Historical Society

P. L. Sperr collection
Received Jan. 13, 1945

Broadway from 9th to 1Oth Streets, inclusive. The north building of Wanamaker's department store is shown; the south building has not yet been erected. In the background is Grace Church (Protestant Episcopal). Fleischmann's Vienna Model Bakery, which stood on the N.E. corner of 10th Street,has been demolished, and the lot will still be vacant in 1935.
About 1910.
Ewing Galloway.

9th Street, (east), north side, east from Broadway, to the East River. Also shown is Broadway, at the N.E. corner of East 9th Street.
Prominent Building is Wanamaker's Dept. Store.
About 1925.
Ae e 6S :

Broadway, east side, north from East 9th (Wanamaker Place) to and including 10th Streets, showing the north building of John Wanamaker's Department Store and Grace Protestant Episcopal Church. Note the NRA banner on Wanamaker's flagstaff. At the date of this picture the National Industrial Recovery Act was only five months old and the National Recovery Administration (NRA) had recently been established, headed by General HAugh S. Johnson. The NRA Was greeted with enthusiasm which closely resembled war-time hysteria. An NRA parade took place in September of this year (see Parades for phctographs) which was the largest in New Vork 's history, surpassing even the war parades. Later, however, the popularity of NRA waned and early in 1935 it was declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court in the Schechter case, popularly called
the "sick chicken" case.
October 19, 1933.

Broadway at N.W. corner of 9th Street.
June 5, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

49 East 9th Street, north side, between Broadway and University Place, showing the O. Henry House, in which the renowned American author of
short stories lived.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

[this is misplaced on the interactive map]

Broadway, north from East 9th Street, showing Grace P. E. Church at the N. E. corner of 9th Street. On the right is the north building of Wannamakers Department Store. The clock tower in the background is atop the Consolidated Edison Building at Irving Place and 14th Street.
April 12, 1940
P. L. Sperr
